docs.snippet: If we are looking for a satisfying verdict on this World Cup, then it is possibly inappropriate to turn to one of the most ruthless criminals that the small screen has ever seen. But Marlo Stanfield, the scourge of Baltimore's police force in the HBO...
docs.lead_paragraph: If we are looking for a satisfying verdict on this World Cup, then it is possibly inappropriate to turn to one of the most ruthless criminals that the small screen has ever seen. But Marlo Stanfield, the scourge of Baltimore's police force in the HBO cult classic "The Wire," had the best words to describe the tournament.
docs.abstract: If we are looking for a satisfying verdict on this World Cup, then it is possibly inappropriate to turn to one of the most ruthless criminals that the small screen has ever seen. But Marlo Stanfield, the scourge of Baltimore's police force in the HBO cult classic "The Wire," had the best words to describe the tournament.

headline.main: A World Cup as Unpredictable as the Flight Pattern of a Jabulani

docs.snippet: Nick Fitzhugh and Pete Muller share their stories as they work on their documentary series about the cultural importance and significance of soccer in black South Africa.
docs.lead_paragraph: Nick Fitzhugh and Pete Muller are in South Africa to produce a documentary series and film about the cultural importance and significance of soccer in black South Africa. Based in Alexandra -- a four-square-kilometer township in Johannesburg inhabited by about 1.5 million people -- the series centers around five people whose lives have been defined by soccer. They are sharing some of their stories with us.
docs.abstract: Nick Fitzhugh and Pete Muller share their stories as they work on their documentary series about the cultural importance and significance of soccer in black South Africa.
